trending.reason: Telstra and SQC complete quantum reservoir trial to enhance network predictions
Breakthrough Quantum-secure Link Protects Data Using Laws Of Physics

articles.title: Telstra and SQC Complete Quantum Reservoir Trial to Enhance Network Predictions
articles.excerpt: Telstra and Silicon Quantum Computing (SQC) have successfully trialled a quantum-enhanced machine learning system to solve complex network challenges, taking quantum computing out of the lab and into a real-world application.

articles.author: Telstra Writer
articles.fullContent:
Quantum Computing Moves From Lab to Field Application

In a significant advancement for Australian technology, Telstra and Silicon Quantum Computing (SQC) have applied quantum computing to enhance predictive analytics for telecommunications networks. The joint team explored how quantum-enhanced machine learning could improve Telstra's response to complex connectivity challenges.

Testing a Quantum Reservoir

The collaboration tested SQC's quantum-enhanced machine learning system, known as Watermelon, which functions as a quantum reservoir. This system was tasked with forecasting network metrics using real, historical network data on SQC's locally developed silicon-based quantum processor. The goal was to determine if features generated by the quantum reservoir could effectively predict network performance and compare it against existing deep learning models.

"For us, we see this as huge breakthrough demonstration on how quantum-enhanced AI could realistically be used within the telco industry and on the Telstra network."

- Telstra

Breakthrough Results and Future Implications

The trial yielded impressive results. The quantum reservoir model achieved comparable accuracy to the existing deep learning model but was trained and fine-tuned in just a few days, compared to the weeks required for the conventional model. This demonstrates a significant potential for quantum-enhanced AI in the telecommunications industry.

What is a Quantum Reservoir?

A quantum reservoir uses the properties of quantum mechanics to process input data in a rich, dynamic way. In this trial, it analysed vast streams of telco data, such as call logs and latency, to identify patterns and make predictions more efficiently than classical systems.

A Foundation for the Future

This successful trial lays the groundwork for broader investigations into quantum technology for digital infrastructure and other real-world industry applications. The collaboration between Telstra, an investor in SQC, and the quantum computing firm highlights how Australian industry and homegrown innovation can drive the nation's digital future.

Key Takeaways

  • Telstra and SQC successfully trialled a quantum-enhanced machine learning system on real network data.
  • The quantum reservoir, named Watermelon, achieved comparable accuracy to existing deep learning models.
  • Training and fine-tuning the quantum model took only a few days, a significant speed increase over the weeks required for the conventional model.
  • The trial represents a major step in moving quantum computing from theoretical research to practical industry applications.

articles.title: Breakthrough Quantum-Secure Link Deployed in Australia
articles.excerpt: A collaboration between QuintessenceLabs, CSIRO, and AARNet has resulted in a breakthrough quantum-secure live link, designed to protect critical data from future cyber threats using the laws of physics.
articles.bannerImage: data:image/svg+xml;utf8,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 1200 800" width="1200" height="800" role="img" aria-label="Fallback image for Quantum Secure Link"><defs><linearGradient id="grad2" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="100%" y2="0%"><stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:%230D47A1;stop-opacity:1" /><stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:%2342A5F5;stop-opacity:1" /></linearGradient></defs><rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(%23grad2)" /><path d="M-200,0 a200,200 0 1,0 400,0 a200,200 0 1,0 -400,0" fill="none" stroke="%23FFFFFF" stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.2" transform="translate(600 400)"><animateTransform attributeName="transform" type="rotate" from="0 600 400" to="360 600 400" dur="10s" repeatCount="indefinite" /></path><path d="M-300,0 a300,300 0 1,0 600,0 a300,300 0 1,0 -600,0" fill="none" stroke="%23FFFFFF" stroke-width="2" stroke-opacity="0.3" transform="translate(600 400)"><animateTransform attributeName="transform" type="rotate" from="360 600 400" to="0 600 400" dur="15s" repeatCount="indefinite" /></path><text x="50%" y="90%" dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle" font-family="'Segoe UI', sans-serif" font-size="32" fill="white" font-weight="bold">Quantum-Secure Communication Link</text></svg>
articles.thumbnailImage: data:image/svg+xml;utf8,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 400 300" width="400" height="300" role="img" aria-label="Fallback thumbnail for Quantum Secure Link"><defs><linearGradient id="gradThumb2" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="100%" y2="0%"><stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:%230D47A1;stop-opacity:1" /><stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:%2342A5F5;stop-opacity:1" /></linearGradient></defs><rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(%23gradThumb2)" /><text x="50%" y="50%" dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle" font-family="'Segoe UI', sans-serif" font-size="24" fill="white" font-weight="bold">Quantum-Secure Link</text></svg>
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.fullContent:
Australian Tech Delivers Live Quantum-Secure Link

Australian technology has produced a live quantum-secure link, a significant development that aims to future-proof sensitive data against emerging cyber threats. The project combines the expertise of QuintessenceLabs, Australia's national science agency CSIRO, and the national research and education network, AARNet.

Unbreakable Encryption with Quantum Key Distribution

The collaboration has successfully demonstrated a quantum key distribution (QKD) system operating over standard optical fibre. This technology generates unbreakable encryption keys rooted in the laws of physics, countering the threat of 'harvest now, decrypt later' attacks where encrypted data is stolen and stored until future computers can break the code. The QKD system uses tiny signals of light to create secret codes between two points.

"Our ambition was to enable the nation to develop and test future-proof cybersecurity innovations using the laws of physics — and we've achieved an important milestone."

- Dr Seyit Camtepe, CSIRO cyber and quantum security research scientist

Successful Deployment and Next Steps

Using a new 12.7-kilometre AARNet fibre loop at CSIRO's Marsfield site in Sydney, QuintessenceLabs deployed its qOptica continuous variable QKD system. Despite real-world fibre losses, the link produced strong secret key rates, proving its readiness for practical application. This marks one of the first publicly documented deployments of QKD over telecom-grade dark fibre in Australia. The team's next objective is to extend the live link to cover longer distances across cities and states.

Key Takeaways

  • A partnership between QuintessenceLabs, CSIRO, and AARNet has created a live quantum-secure link in Australia.
  • The system uses Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) to generate unbreakable encryption keys based on the laws of physics.
  • It was successfully deployed over a 12.7km AARNet fibre loop in Sydney, demonstrating its viability for practical use.
  • The technology aims to protect long-lived data like health and financial records from future decryption by quantum computers.

articles.title: Archer Materials Advances Qubit Development After EDMR Breakthrough
articles.excerpt: Quantum technology company Archer Materials has announced further progress in its carbon-based qubit technology, building on its recent breakthrough in on-chip electrical detection of magnetic resonance (EDMR).
articles.bannerImage: data:image/svg+xml;utf8,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 1200 800" width="1200" height="800" role="img" aria-label="Fallback image for Archer Materials Qubit Tech"><defs><linearGradient id="grad3" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%"><stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:%2337474F;stop-opacity:1" /><stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:%2378909C;stop-opacity:1" /></linearGradient></defs><rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(%23grad3)" /><g opacity="0.5"><circle cx="200" cy="200" r="150" stroke="white" stroke-width="2" fill="none" /><line x1="200" y1="50" x2="200" y2="350" stroke="white" stroke-width="2" /><line x1="50" y1="200" x2="350" y2="200" stroke="white" stroke-width="2" /><circle cx="950" cy="600" r="100" stroke="white" stroke-width="2" fill="none" /></g><text x="50%" y="90%" dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle" font-family="'Segoe UI', sans-serif" font-size="32" fill="white" font-weight="bold">Archer Materials Qubit Advancement</text></svg>
articles.thumbnailImage: data:image/svg+xml;utf8,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 400 300" width="400" height="300" role="img" aria-label="Fallback thumbnail for Archer Materials Qubit Tech"><defs><linearGradient id="gradThumb3" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%"><stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:%2337474F;stop-opacity:1" /><stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:%2378909C;stop-opacity:1" /></linearGradient></defs><rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(%23gradThumb3)" /><text x="50%" y="50%" dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle" font-family="'Segoe UI', sans-serif" font-size="24" fill="white" font-weight="bold">Qubit Advancement</text></svg>
articles.author: Sharecafe
articles.fullContent:
Progress in Carbon-Based Qubit Technology

Archer Materials, a quantum technology company developing advanced semiconductor chips, is building on its July breakthrough in on-chip electrical detection of magnetic resonance (EDMR). This earlier achievement provided a clear readout method for the company's qubits and demonstrated the potential for highly sensitive quantum sensing and computing applications.

Engineering Smaller, Scalable Devices

The EDMR result allowed Archer to electrically detect quantum spin states in its carbon qubit material directly on a chip, which opens the possibility for smaller, more scalable, and more easily manufactured devices. Recent engineering work has focused on refining gating and single-electron transistor (SET) architectures in carbon film, with the team achieving reproducible device performance. This is a critical step for controlling charge and spin at the nanoscale.

"Progress on these key 2025 milestones further strengthens the company's technical leadership in developing world-leading quantum technology."

- Dr Simon Ruffell, CEO of Archer

Material Scaling and Future Goals

In addition to device refinement, Archer has successfully scaled the synthesis of its carbon-based quantum material to a 1-inch silicon wafer. The company also achieved electron spin lifetimes exceeding 0.4 microseconds at room temperature, reinforcing its technology's advantages over other approaches. With a targeted qubit demonstration in mid-2026, Archer is positioning itself at the forefront of quantum innovation.

Key Takeaways

  • Archer Materials is advancing its carbon-based qubit technology following a breakthrough in on-chip EDMR.
  • The EDMR result enables the electrical detection of quantum spin states, paving the way for smaller, more scalable devices.
  • The company has achieved reproducible device performance and scaled its quantum material synthesis to a 1-inch silicon wafer.
  • Archer is aiming for a full qubit demonstration by mid-2026.
